title-group.article-title: Modeling and analysis of roundness error in friction drilling of aluminum silicon carbide metal matrix composite

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, College of Engineering Guindy, Anna University, Chennai, India
2Sri Sairam Institute of Technology, Sai Leo Nagar, Chennai, India

author-notes.corresp: G. Somasundaram, Department of Mechanical Engineering, College of Engineering Guindy, Anna University, Chennai, India Email: g_somasundaram@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Friction drilling is a newer nontraditional hole-making chipless process, which is used to make holes in materials that are used in aerospace, automotive, commercial and industrial products, electronic packaging, and thermal management. In friction drilling, a rotating conical tool is applied to penetrate work-material and create a hole in single step. In this study, comprehensive analysis on friction drilling of Al/SiCp metal matrix composites is carried out. This article discusses the roundness (hole diameter accuracy) errors on dry friction-drilled holes. The parameters considered for the experiment are: the composition of workpiece, workpiece thickness, spindle speed, and feed rate. The effect of parameters on roundness errors is analyzed using experimental design matrix and empirical relation between the process parameters and roundness error is established using response surface methodology. Analysis of variance is used for analyzing the results. The influences of individual input process parameters on roundness error are analyzed and presented in this study.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Discontinuous reinforced metal matrix composite is one of the developments in the field of material engineering and it offers various advantages over conventional materials such as improved strength, specific modulus, high toughness, and good wear-resisting property even at elevated temperatures. Due to its unique advantages, it is extensively used in structural, aerospace, and automobile applications.1

Discontinuously reinforced aluminum (DRA) MMCs find increased application in different industries owing to their properties. They have isotropic properties and provide specific stiffness values that are higher than those of aerospace metal alloys by as much as 100%. The most widely used DRA aerospace materials have volume fractions that range from 15% to 25% of SiCp particles. These materials have isotropic specific stiffness up to 50% higher than that of metal alloys and isotropic specific strengths that are equivalent to those of the best commonly used aerospace metal alloys, such as Ti–6Al–4 V and 7075-T6 aluminum. These MMCs also provide specific stiffness equivalent to that of the best graphite/epoxy cross-plied material and have specific strengths in the midrange of cross-plied organic composites.2 Tosun and Muratoglu3 reported that Al/SiCp MMCs are extremely difficult to machine – turning, milling, drilling, and threading – due to their abrasive properties. They have conducted drilling studies on Al/17%/SiC particulate metal matrix composite (PMMC) with TiN-coated high-speed steel (HSS) drills. They found that the surface roughness decreased with increase in cutting speed and reasoned it with the burnishing or honing effect by the rubbing action of small SiC particles trapped between tool and workpiece.

The researchers are finding some difficulty in drilling of composite materials by ordinary drilling. Davim andBaptista4 used a substance harder than SiC, polycrystalline diamond (PCD) drills to make holes in aluminum with 7.0% silicon and 0.4% magnesium, reinforced with 20% by volume silicon carbide (SiC) particles. Basavarajappa et al.5 studied the influence of cutting parameters (cutting speed, feed rate, and their interaction) on burr formation in drilling of Al/SiCp and Al/SiCp–Gr composites with carbide and coated carbide drills. They applied L9 orthogonal array based on Taguchi techniques and found that statistical models developed by them can be used for the prediction of burr height in drilling MMCs using different tool materials.

In this context, a novel drilling process using a friction tool is experimented here for its effectiveness in drilling Al/SiCp MMC plates of varied thickness. Friction drilling is a nontraditional hole-making method that utilizes the heat generated from friction between a rotating conical tool and the workpiece to soften and penetrate the work-material and generate a hole in the work piece. Materials with higher strength should require more thrust force to be penetrated. Friction drilling is also called thermal drilling, flow drilling, form drilling, or friction stir drilling. In this novel process, safe clearance space must be provided at the top and bottom of the work-material being drilled for the extruded work material to form petals/protrusions. Bushing formation will take place when the protrusions of the hole are forced down by the collar of the tool.

A bushing and petal formation around the drilled holes are unavoidable in friction drilling but are well tolerated in the case of Al alloy and any material with low elongation at break (%). For Al alloy, due to the fracture or peeling in the bushing-forming process during friction drilling, much of the work-material is improperly displaced and does not form a proper bushing. But the deformation and fracture of work-material to form petals are not well understood.6

These bushing formations are used advantageously by many researchers for lengthening the threaded portion of the hole and consequently increase the fastener clamp load in subsequent assembly operations. This clean and chipless friction drilling process has the advantage of reducing the time required for drilling and incurring less tool wear, thus lengthening the service life of the drill. In friction drilling AISI Steel by Miller et al.,7 minimal tool wear is reported after producing 11,000 holes and they noted the change in diameter between hole numbers 1 and 11,000 is 0.29 mm, which is near the bottom of the bushing at a depth of 4.46 mm. The performance of the sintered carbide friction drill was compared with the Tungsten carbide (WC) twist drill in drilling AISI-304 material by Chow et al.8 They concluded that WC twist drill damaged seriously after three drilling runs but the friction drill showed little wear only after 60 runs of the drill and also good quality hole surface is obtained.

Friction drilling of Al/SiCp MMC plates is advantageous owing to the minimal friction tool wear and improved hole quality. Depending on the thermal conductivity and frictional energy generated during drilling, this localized heating can reduce the magnitude of work hardening that would otherwise occur by deformation alone. The heat generation associated with the friction drilling process is of less concern in the case of friction drilling of Al/SiCp MMC plates as this material is a good thermal conductor.9

One of the most common roundness problems in drilled holes is the existence of the spaced lobes due to low-frequency vibrations. A mathematical model to predict some properties of holes such as cylindricity, roundness, and perpendicularity values was developed by Pirtini and Lazoglu.10 Hole diameter accuracy (roundness errors) and the surface finish inside the hole are the important qualities or the characteristics of holes required in the aerospace industry. In dry drilling of aluminum alloy, aluminum adheres to the tool and clogs the flutes resulting in tool failure. Drill performance and hole quality are mainly dependent on the cutting parameters and tools.11 Hence, to reduce the wear of tool and cost of making flutes of the drill, a fluteless friction drill is studied.

Shin Min Lee et al.12 concluded that the coated drills had higher surface temperature than uncoated ones. However, the difference in performance between coated and uncoated drills diminished with increase in number of holes drilled. Gaitonde et al.13 conducted machining experiment with aluminum alloy reinforced with 20% of SiC particulates (A 356/20/SiCp-T6) using a PCD tool and did mathematical model using response surface methodology (RSM). They concluded that the machining force and cutting power increase with increase in feed rate while the specific cutting force decreases.

The literature available on friction drilling of Al/SiCp MMC plates and on roundness error of drilled holes is very limited. In the recent past to the knowledge of the authors, neither systematic work nor modeling of process parameter is carried out in friction drilling of Al/SiC composites. Hence, in this study, a comprehensive analysis has been carried out for friction drilling of Al/SiCp MMCs with low range of SiC composition excluding bushing formation and including hole quality in terms of roundness error.

A mathematical model has been developed to predict the roundness errors of drilled Al/SiCp MMC plates using response surface method. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is used to check the validity of the model.14 This model can be effectively used to predict the roundness errors of drilled Al/SiCp MMC plates. This friction drilling process will pave way for reducing the tool wear and reducing time in manufacturing and the objective is the successful application of friction drill in making holes with very less tool wear.

sec.title: Investigation on friction drilling of Al/SiC composite
sec.p:
The investigation is planned in the following sequence:
Identifying the predominant factors (machining parameters), which have influence on roundness variations of the drilled Al/SiCp MMC plates and find the upper and lower limits of chosen factors.
Developing the experimental design matrix.
Conducting the experiments as per the design matrix.
Developing the mathematical model.
Calculating the coefficients of the model.
Checking the adequacy of the developed model by ANOVA method.
Analyzing the effect of different parameters on roundness variations.

sec.title: Identification of predominant factors and finding the upper and lower limits of chosen factors
sec.p: Friction drilling is one of the novel processes in which the drilling is controlled by many factors. For the aluminum alloy, the thermal conductivity is high. A large portion of the frictional heat is transferred into the workpiece and the effect of friction heating is relatively small. Low temperature causes insufficient increase in ductility and softening, resulting in high thrust force, denting of the workpiece, and improper bushing formation.

These effects dictated the selection of spindle speeds.9 During friction drilling, the surface temperature of drills increases with increase in spindle speed and it also increases with repeated drillings or number of holes drilled which is due to the adhesion of tool to workpiece.12 Davim and Conceicao António15 found that while drilling 15-mm thick PMMC discs, with PCD twist drills to cut 5 mm diameter holes at a constant cutting speed, the surface finish of the holes of the drilled samples deteriorates with increasing feed rate but does not change signiﬁcantly with varying cutting speed. From the available literature, it was found that apart from cutting speed and tool feed rate, composition of SiCp particles and plate thickness may have influence on the hole quality.

Based on the literature and trial work done on these cutting parameters for friction-drilled aluminum alloy by author,16 the independently controllable predominant drilling parameters that have greater influences on the roundness variations of the friction-drilled Al/SiCp MMC plates have been identified. They are:
spindle speed (S);
feed rate (F),
wt% of SiCp (W); and
plate thickness (P).
Detailed analysis6 is carried to fix the upper and lower limits of the factors.

The factors used, notations, units, and their levels are presented in Table 1. Table 1.
Important factors and their levels
S. no. Parameter Notation Levels
(−2) (−1) 0 (+1) (+2)
1. Spindle speed (rpm) S(X1) 2000 2500 3000 3500 4000
2. Tool feed rate (mm/min) F(X2) 40 50 60 70 80
3. Wt% of SiCp W(X3) 5 10 15 20 25
4. Plate thickness (mm) P(X4) 2 2.5 3 3.5 4

sec.title: Developing the experimental design matrix
sec.p:
Considering the slightly wider ranges of the factors, a five-level, central composite, rotatable design matrix is used for experimentation. Central composite rotatable designs (CCD) of second order have been found to be the most efficient tool in RSM to establish the mathematical relation of the response surface using the smallest possible number of experiments without losing its accuracy. In the present case, the size of the experiment is 31 for four machining parameters. The design is subdivided into three parts as shown below.14,17,18
The points constituting a 2k factorial design, i.e., 16 points; k is the number of input variables.
The extra points are included to form a CCD with α. The figure formed by these points is called a star. The number of star points is 8 for four machining parameters.
The extra seven points are added at the center to give roughly equal precision for response roundness within a circle of radius 1.

Table 2 shows the 31 sets of cutting conditions used to form the central CCD matrix. It comprises full replication of 24 = 16 factorial design plus 7 center points and 8 star points. All the chosen variables at the intermediate level (0) constitute the center points and the combinations of each of the variables are either the lowest (−2) or the highest (+2) with the other three variables of the intermediate levels constituting the star points. Thus, the 31 experimental runs allowed the estimation of the linear, quadratic, and two-way interactive offers of the variables on the roundness error. The method of designing such a matrix is dealt with by Cochran and Cox.18 Table 2.
The layout of central CCD with results
S. no. Spindle speed, S (rpm) Feed rate, F (mm/min) Wt.% of SiCp, W Thickness of plate, P (mm) Roundness error (µm)

19 3000 40 15 3 151

21 3000 60 5 3 222

28 3000 60 15 3 168
29 3000 60 15 3 192
30 3000 60 15 3 175
31 3000 60 15 3 182

The value of any intermediate levels can be calculated using the following expression.19 (1) where Xmax is the upper level of the parameter, Xmin the lower level of the parameter, and Xi the required values of the parameter of from Xmin to Xmax.

sec.title: Experimental procedure
sec.p:
Al/SiCp MMC plates containing five levels of composition of SiC particles (5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 wt%) of mean particle size 37 µm were prepared using a melt stirring–gravity casting route. The matrix material was BS 1490 Grade LM6 aluminum casting alloy. The chemical composition of the matrix is given in Table 3. Prior to the particulate addition, 0.5 wt% Mg was also added to improve the wetting capability of reinforcements.20 Table 3.
The composition of aluminum matrix used
Element Si Fe Cu Mn Mg Zn Ni Pb Sn Ti Al
Percentage 10–13 0.6 0.1 0.5 0.1 0.1 0.1 0.1 0.005 0.2 Remaining

Friction drilling is one of the important operations in manufacturing engineering getting importance due to its simplest operation. Figure 1 illustrates the stages in friction drilling of Al/SiCp MMC workpiece. First, the tool comes into initial contact with the workpiece, as shown in Figure 1(a). Next, at the main thrust stage, the tool penetrates the workpiece and a high axial force is encountered, as shown in Figure 1(b). Figure 1.
Stages in friction drilling process.

The friction associated with the friction drilling between the contact surfaces produces heat which softens the work-material and the protrusions of the displaced workpiece material starts appearing, as shown in Figure 1(c). The tool is advanced further, and the protrusions of the displaced workpiece material starts appearing above as well as below the workpiece, as shown in Figure 1(d). Provision for the movement of protruding metal is necessary. Figure 1(e) shows the material separation stage, where the tool penetrates through the workpiece and makes a hole. Finally, the tool retracts with minimal friction and leaves a hole with protrusions on the workpiece, Figure 1(f).6

The drilling tests were performed at ARIX – CNC machining center manufactured by ARIX CNC machine Co. Ltd., Taiwan. The specification of the machine used is given below:
Capacity – X-axis: 700 mm
Capacity – Y-axis: 300 mm
Capacity – Z-axis: 150 mm
Table size: 1270 × 254 mm2
Spindle speed range: 60–5000 rpm
Maximum feed: 3000 mm

The workpiece was kept on Hylam sheet to insulate the heat generated by friction drilling and clamped firmly as there was a tendency to rotate the workpiece because of the high torque involved. All the trials are carried out according to the order presented in the Table 2 using fresh tool for every set. The experimental setup used in this study is presented in Figure 2(a) and (b). The holes are drilled using friction drill specially fabricated using HSS material. In this study, the ratio of t/d (thickness of plate-to-drill diameter) is varied between 0.377 and 0.754. The friction drill used for this study is shown in Figure 3(a) and (b). The tool geometry and key dimensions of the friction drill are provided in Table 4. The tool used for this investigation is TiN-coated HSS with the coating thickness of 4 µm and the coating film hardness is 2800 HV. Table 4.
Friction drilling tool geometry and key dimensions
Diameter, d (mm) α (°) β (°) Center region, length (mm) Conical region, length (mm) Cylindrical region, length/diameter (mm) Shoulder region, length/diameter (mm) Shank region, length/diameter (mm)
5.3 90 36 1 10 15/5.3 7/12 30/10
Figure 2.
Experimental setup used for this investigation.

caption.p: Tool used for friction drilling: (a) picture of the friction tool and (b) line diagram of the tool used.

sec.p:
Pictures of friction-drilled holes on Al/SiCp MMC plates are shown in Figure 4. This picture is taken after friction drilling of the workpiece. The picture shows the protrusion and burrs formed on the workpiece. After the drilling operation, the protrusion and burrs of the drilled holes are removed and smoothened using flat file. The smoothened hole is presented in Figure 5. Figure 4.
Close-up view of friction-drilled holes with protrusions and burr.
Figure 5.
Smoothened holes after hand filing.

The plates were used in as cast condition for the experiments. The composite plate materials were faced and cut to a plate of 100 mm × 100 mm and thickness values 2, 2.5,3, 3.5, and 4 mm. The roundness errors21 were measured using Carl-Zeiss Rondcom 54 and given in Table 2. Rondcoms use the TIMS software strategy which includes trace input for contours, R-axisfollow for roundness and three-point alignment. The roundness tester used and the roundness profile observed are shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
(a) Roundness profiles observed in drilling MMC plates using friction drill and (b) roundness tester used. Note: Drilling parameters for holes in: Top left: 3000 rpm spindle speed; 60 mm/min feed; 25 wt% of SiC; 3 mm thick. Top right: 2500 rpm spindle speed; 50 mm/min feed; 20 wt% of SiC; 3.5 mm thick. Bottom left: 3000 rpm spindle speed; 60 mm/min feed; 15 wt% of SiC; 4 mm thick. Bottom right: 3000 rpm spindle speed; 60 mm/min feed; 5 wt% of SiC; 3 mm thick.

sec.title: Development of mathematical model to predict the roundness errors
Developing the model
sec.p: Representing the roundness errors as ‘Re’, the response function can be expressed as (2)
The model chosen was a second-degree response surface and is expressed as follows: (3)
The values of the coefficients have been calculated by regression with the help of Equations (4)–(7).18 (4) (5) (6) (7)
The final model is developed in coded units and is given in Equation (8) as follows:
Roundness error, Re, (8)

sec.title: Checking the adequacy of the developed model
sec.p:
The adequacy of the model is checked using the ANOVA technique. As per this technique, if the calculated value of the F-ratio of the developed model does not exceed the standard tabulated value of F-ratio for a desired level of confidence (say 99%), then the model is considered to be adequate within the confidence limit. ANOVA test results are presented in the Table 5. The lack-of-fit was found to be less than F0.01 (10, 6) in this research study and, hence the developed model may be accepted.14 Further, the experimental data and the predicted data using the aforesaid model are plotted, as shown in Figure 7, which indicates a good correlation. Table 5.
ANOVA for surface profile
Source df Seq SS Adj SS Adj MS F P
Regression 14 62,990.3 62,990.3 4499.31 62.47 0
Linear 4 30,905.6 30,905.6 7726.4 107.28 0
Square 4 10,678 10,678 2669.49 37.07 0
Interaction 6 21,406.7 21,406.7 3567.79 49.54 0
Residual error 16 1152.3 1152.3 72.02
Lack-of-fit 10 431.9 431.9 43.19 0.36 0.926
Pure error 6 720.5 720.5 120.08
Total 30 64,142.6
Figure 7.
Correlations graph for roundness error.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study proved the successful application of friction drill in making holes of Al/SiCp MMC plates with very less tool wear and this method may increase the production rate, even though further filing operation is required.

Figure 8(a) and (b) shows the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the inner surface of the friction-drilled hole. For the purpose of presenting finished plate with holes, the protrusions are removed by filing. Filing does not make appreciable change in the mechanical properties and also its impact on microstructural changes is very limited. Figure 8.
SEM images of inner surface of the friction-drilled hole. Note: At 60×, variations in the inner surface of the friction-drilled hole with drilling parameters: (a) 3500 rpm spindle speed; 70 mm/min feed; 10 wt% of SiC; 3.5 mm thick. (b) 3500 rpm spindle speed; 50 mm/min feed; 10 wt% of SiC; 3.5 mm thick. At 500×, Variations in the inner surface of the friction drilled hole showing embedded SiC particles with drilling parameters: (c) 3500 rpm spindle speed; 70 mm/min feed; 20 wt% of SiC; 2.5 mm thick; and (d) 2500 rpm spindle speed; 70 mm/min feed; 20 wt% of SiC; 2.5 mm thick.

Filing is normally a common process in drilling for removing of burrs and it is also necessary for the measurement purpose. Figure 8(b) is free from visible markings in comparison with Figure 8(a) owing to the change in cutting condition. The thin white lines are the tip of the grain that have oxidized and formed Al2O3. Figure 8(c) and (d) shows SEM images of the inner surface of the friction-drilled hole. The matrix shows the presence of SiCp particles embedded in it. High temperature and pressure during the process force the SiCp particles to get trapped in the soft metal matrix.

Figure 9(a) and (b) shows the SEM images of surface of the extruded chips of friction-drilled hole. The grains of the extruded chip of the friction-drilled hole have undergone plastic deformation due to the force, speed, and the temperature which is near the superplastic range. Figure 9(c) and (d) shows the SEM images of surface of the extruded chips of friction-drilled hole at high magnification. The tiny worm-like phases/particles observed in the figure are Al–Si eutectic and are those present in the aluminum solid solution. The material is hypereutectic Al–Si alloy. Figure 9.
(a)–(d) SEM images of surface of extruded chip of the friction drilled hole. Note: At 1000×, variations in the surface of the extruded chips with drilling parameters: (a) 3000 rpm spindle speed; 60 mm/min feed; 5 wt% of SiC; 3 mm thick and (b) 3000 rpm spindle speed; 60 mm/min feed; 25 wt% of SiC; 3 mm thick. At 3000×, variations in the surface of the extruded chips with drilling parameters: (c) 3000 rpm spindle speed; 60 mm/min feed; 5 wt% of SiC; 3 mm thick. (d) 3000 rpm spindle speed; 60 mm/min feed; 25 wt% of SiC; 3 mm thick.

The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis is carried out for the workpiece material in the inner surface of the friction-drilled hole and is presented in Figure 10. EDX profile indicates the presence of more silicon in the workpiece. It is due to the presence of silicon in the matrix aluminum alloy as well in the added SiCp particles. The abrasive nature of the SiCp particles is the major reason for the wear on the tool3,4 and in this study, the friction tool will not try to cut these abrasive particles but push them in. Thermal softening is believed to take place in machining of Al/SiCp MMC composites where the workpiece material becomes softer due to the heat generated and SiCp particles become pressed into the workpiece.22 This phenomenon is the main cause of minimal tool wear in friction drilling. The tool profile after drilling 400 holes is presented in Figure 11. In this figure, no tool wear is noticed but aluminum adhering to the tip of the tool is visible as the white portion. Figure 10.
EDX profile observed in the inner surface of friction drilled hole with drilling parameters: 2500 rpm spindle speed; 70 mm/min feed; 10% wt% of SiC; 3.5 mm thick.
Figure 11.
Picture of the friction tool after drilling 400 holes.

The influence of different machining parameters like spindle speed, feed, percentage weight fraction of SiC, and thickness of the workpiece on roundness error has been analyzed based on the developed mathematical model.

The plots of the roundness error vs. machining parameters considered have been prepared and presented in Figure 12 to illustrate the trend of variation of roundness error with various friction drilling parameters. Figure 12.
Variation of roundness errors (µm): (a) spindle speed (rpm), (b) feed rate (mm/min), (c) wt% of SiC (%), and (d) thickness of plate (mm).

Variation of roundness errors with respect to different spindle speeds is shown in Figure12(a). Roundness error which is maximum at 3000 rpm owing to the instability of the tool is due to the imbalance of the cutting force. The graph indicates that, the increase of spindle speed increases the roundness error up to 3000 rpm and then reduces. Speed of 3000 rpm may be considered as a critical one and after that the roundness error will reduce in friction drilling of Al/SiCp composite material. The reason being at higher speed, stability of the tool taking place as the matrix and SiCp particles are pushed out easily which makes easy penetration of the tool, thereby producing good roundness. The general trend is that the roundness errors are minimal at lower and higher ranges of spindle speed with peaking at 3000 rpm.

Figure 12(b) illustrates the variation of roundness errors with respect to different tool feeds. Roundness errors are minimal at 50 mm/min owing to the reduced contact time of the tool with the workpiece and the associated heat generated is sufficient for the penetration of the tool with less thrust force and torque. Further increase of feed though reduces the contact time of the tool with the workpiece, increases thrust force, associated vibrations and thereby increases the roundness error. The general trend is that the roundness errors are increasing with increase in feed values minimal at 50 mm/min.

Variation graph of roundness errors with respect to different weight fractions is drawn in Figure 12(c). Roundness errors are minimal at the middle range mainly owing to the number of SiCp particles present at the tool–workpiece interaction area, which is supporting the hole formation by disintegrating themselves from the matrix for the penetration of the tool with less thrust force and torque.16 This may be the major contributing factor for the high value of roundness error at 5 wt% of SiCp. More deviation at the 25 wt% of SiCp particles may be due to the clustering behavior of the particles when their number is large enough.23 The general trend is that the roundness errors are minimal at midrange of wt% and maximal at the lower and higher ranges.

Figure12(d) depicts the variation of roundness errors with respect to plate thickness. Roundness errors are stable at and above 3 mm owing to the tool stability due to the presence of the newly drilled surface and heat retained by the plate for easy plastic deformation.

The graph indicates that the increase of plate thickness increases the roundness error up to 3 mm due to the instability of the tool. The general trend is that the roundness errors are increasing with increase in plate thickness minimal at 2 mm. The curve exhibits a tendency of roundness errors reducing with increase in plate thickness as the graph is not sloping upward.

From the above analysis, it has been asserted that medium spindle speed, less feed rate, medium weight percentage of SiC, and low thickness of plate are preferred in friction drilling of Al/SiC Composites.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
Mathematical model for roundness has been developed to correlate the important machining parameters in friction drilling of Al/SiCp MMC workpiece. The experimental plan is of rotatable central composite design. The four important input variables considered for this research study is spindle speed, tool feed rate, thickness of the workpiece, and weight percentage of SiCp. The influences of all machining parameters on roundness have been analyzed based on the developed mathematical model. The following conclusions are drawn based on this study:
The roundness error increases gradually with the increase in spindle speed within the range of 2000–3000 rpm and then reduces until 4000 rpm. The general trend is that at lower and higher values of spindle speed, the roundness error is lower. Minimal value is at 2000 rpm.
The roundness error increases with the increase in feed rate within the range of 50 to 80 mm/min. The general trend is that the roundness errors are increasing with increase in feed values. Minimal value is at 50 mm/min.
The roundness error decreases with the increase in weight percentage of SiCp within the range 5–15% and then increases up to 25%. The general trend is that the roundness error is higher at lower and higher values of wt% of SiC, it is lower at the midrange.
The roundness error increases with the increase in the thickness of plates within the range 2–3.5 mm and there exists a negative trend afterwards. The general trend is that roundness error increases with increase of plate thickness. Minimal value is at 2 mm.
This technique is convenient to predict the main effects and interaction effects of different influential combinations of machining parameters.
Though the number of experimentations is slightly more, this technique is still economical to arrive at the influences of various parameters in a systematic manner.
The procedure can be used to predict the roundness errors for friction drilling of Al/SiCp MMC composites within the ranges of the variable studied. However, the validity of the procedure is mostly limited to the range of factors considered for the experimentation.
